title: 103_hr1100
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Multiparty, Multiforum Jurisdiction Act of 1993" and pertains to the jurisdiction of district courts. The "Multiparty, Multiforum Jurisdiction Act of 1993" amends Chapter 85 of title 28, United States Code, by adding a new section regarding the jurisdiction of district courts in civil actions involving minimal diversity between adverse parties arising from a single accident with specific criteria. The new section added to Chapter 85 of title 28, United States Code, establishes jurisdiction for district courts in civil actions involving minimal diversity between adverse parties arising from a single accident based on specific criteria related to defendants' residency and where the accident occurred. The new section in Chapter 85 of title 28, US Code defines terms like 'injury' as physical harm to a person or property, 'accident' as an event causing death or injury to at least 25 people at a specific location, and 'State' to include various regions. In district court actions falling under this section, individuals with claims from the accident can intervene as plaintiffs. The new section in Chapter 85 of title 28, US Code allows individuals with claims from accidents to intervene as plaintiffs in district court actions. District courts must promptly notify the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation of pending actions. "Section 1391 of title 28, US Code is amended to allow civil actions under section 1368 to be brought in any district where a defendant resides or where the accident occurred. Multidistrict litigation procedures are outlined in the following section." Section 1407 of title 28, United States Code is amended to allow the transferee district court to retain actions transferred under this section for determining liability and punitive damages. Actions retained for liability determination may be remanded for damages determination to the original district court or State court, unless retention is deemed necessary for convenience and justice. Remand is effective 60 days after the transferee court issues an order for determination. An appeal can be made within 60 days after the transferee court determines liability and certifies its intention to remand actions for damages. If an appeal is filed, the remand is on hold until the appeal is resolved. Once the remand is effective, the liability and choice of law determinations are final and not subject to further review. Additionally, an appeal can be made within 60 days of a punitive damages determination by the transferee court. The court of appeals with jurisdiction over the transferee court has the authority to make decisions on remand for damages, which are not reviewable by appeal. The transferee court retains the authority to transfer or dismiss an action based on inconvenient forum. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OF ACTIONS. Section 1441 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow a defendant in a civil action in a State court to remove the action to the district court of the United States under certain conditions. The text discusses the process of removing an action from a State court to a United States district court under specific conditions, including the timing of filing a notice of removal and the liability determination by the district court. When 1407(i) determines liability and requires further proceedings for damages, the district court may remand the action to the State court unless it deems it more convenient and just to retain it. The remand is not effective until 60 days after the district court certifies its intention, allowing for appeals on liability and choice of law determinations. The remand shall not be effective until the appeal has been finally disposed of. Liability and choice of law determinations are not subject to further review. Decisions on damages remand are not reviewable. Actions removed under this subsection are deemed to be under section 1368. District court retains authority to transfer or dismiss actions for inconvenient forum. SEC. 6. CHOICE OF LAW. Sec. 1659 of Chapter 111 of title 28, United States Code, addresses the choice of law in multiparty, multiforum actions. The district court where the action is brought or transferred will determine the applicable substantive law, considering factors like the place of injury, conduct causing the injury, and the parties' principal places of business or domiciles. The court is not bound by state choice of law rules. Sec. 1659 of Chapter 111 of title 28, United States Code, addresses the choice of law in multiparty, multiforum actions. The district court will determine the applicable substantive law based on factors like the place of injury, conduct causing the injury, parties' principal places of business or domiciles, danger of forum shopping, and foreseeability of the choice of law to the parties. The court may allow the application of multiple state laws in exceptional cases. The court will designate a single jurisdiction for all related actions arising from the same accident. The district court determines applicable substantive law in multiparty, multiforum actions. Federal law applies unless specified otherwise. Choice of law continues in remanded actions. SEC. 7. SERVICE OF PROCESS.

    (a) Other Than Subpoenas.--(1) Chapter 113 of title 28, United 
States Code, is amended to allow service of process in multiparty, multiforum actions. Process can be served anywhere within or outside the United States if permitted by law. SEC. 7 amends Chapter 113 of title 28, allowing service of process in multiparty, multiforum actions within or outside the United States if permitted by law. SEC. 8 establishes the effective date for these changes. The amendments made by this Act apply to civil actions if the accident occurred on or after the 90th day after the enactment date.
